title: Tidiness Score-Guided Monte Carlo Tree Search for Visual Tabletop Rearrangement
author: Hogun Kee (Seoul National University), Wooseok Oh (Seoul National University), Minjae Kang (Seoul National University), Hyemin Ahn (UNIST), ..., Songhwai Oh (Seoul National University)
relevance_why: The method for evaluating tidiness through a score-giving discriminator could inform similar metric-driven approaches in the audio domain, particularly in assessing audio scene organization or clarity.
background: The study addresses the problem of autonomously rearranging objects on a tabletop to achieve a tidier arrangement without explicit target configurations.
contribution: This paper introduces Tidiness Score-guided Monte Carlo Tree Search (TSMCTS) to solve the tabletop tidying problem, achieving a tidying success rate of 88.5% in simulations and 85% in real robot experiments.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often specified explicit goals for object rearrangement or relied on limited datasets, making them less adaptable to diverse scenarios.
technical_comparison.novelty: TSMCTS uses a learned tidiness score function as a flexible utility measure instead of strict target positions, allowing for a broader range of tidy configurations.

key_innovation: Combines a tidiness discriminator trained on diverse environment data with Monte Carlo Tree Search to find optimal object arrangements without predefined goals.
real_world_impact: TSMCTS demonstrates robust capabilities in various real-world scenarios, indicating potential deployment in assistive robotics for household tidiness tasks.
limitations: The method assumes a 2D arrangement and may struggle with configurations requiring vertical stacking or complex multi-layer tidiness.

new_terms.tidiness score: **Tidiness score** is a numerical representation of how organized a set of objects on a surface appears, ranging from completely messy (0) to perfectly tidy (1).
new_terms.Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS): **Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS)** is a heuristic search algorithm used to make decisions in some AI applications, employing random sampling and simulation to evaluate potential outcomes.

open_sourcing: The TTU dataset is available at: [https://github.com/rllab-snu/TTU-Dataset](https://github.com/rllab-snu/TTU-Dataset)
